title: PTD Today — Media
disclaimer: Informational only — AI-generated summaries; may contain errors. Verify with the original video.

items.title: How AI Empowers Artists. Watch the full episode on our channel now.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this film accompanies Season 5 of the Webby Award–winning podcast Where the Internet Lives and centers on how AI empowers artists within the unseen world of data centers. It frames creativity and data/AI together, highlighting the infrastructure that supports digital artistic tools.
bullets: Accompanies Season 5 of the Webby Award–winning podcast Where the Internet Lives.
Focuses on the intersection of AI, data, and creativity—specifically how AI empowers artists.
Frames the conversation around the ‘unseen world’ of data centers that enable AI and digital tools.
Published by Google on 2026-01-15.
No transcript is available for the video description provided.
takeaways: Given the film’s emphasis on AI-driven creativity, data center operators should anticipate cultural and commercial demand for reliable, scalable compute and plan capacity and redundancy accordingly.

Storytelling that connects data center infrastructure to visible benefits (creative tools, cultural output) can help operators engage communities and stakeholders during siting and permitting processes.
If creative AI workloads grow, prioritize flexible energy strategies—demand response, on-site storage, and renewables—to manage peak loads and sustainability expectations.
Assess hardware and supply-chain risks (including critical minerals) that underpin AI-capable infrastructure to improve resilience for creative and commercial workloads.
Consider offering tailored service tiers or edge/colocation options for artists and creative platforms that need lower-latency or cost-effective access to AI compute.

items.title: Boosting AI Performance: Networking for AI Inference

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Victor Moreno (Product Manager, Cloud Networking at Google) explains how networking must be AI-aware to support efficient inference. He outlines Google Cloud’s approach—GKE Inference Gateway plus AI-aware load balancing and service extensions—that uses inference-specific metrics, prefix caching, body-based routing and guardrails to reduce latency, maximize GPU utilization, and simplify governance.
bullets: Traditional networking and round-robin load balancing miss GPU saturation and send traffic to congested replicas.
GKE Inference Gateway and AI-aware load balancing use metrics like KV cache utilization and queue depth to pick the least-loaded replicas.
Prefix caching and shadow copies let the gateway reuse prefill computations to avoid repeated work and reduce cold starts.
Body-based routing and LoRA-adapter awareness enable routing by model/context; service extensions let you insert API management and guardrails in the network path.
Network-level guardrails can sanitize or reject prompts before they hit GPUs, preventing wasted compute and improving security.
takeaways: Higher GPU saturation from AI-aware routing can reduce total cost of ownership and lower required compute capacity—important for data center procurement and power budgeting.
By avoiding wasted GPU cycles (e.g., rejecting invalid prompts at the edge), facilities can cut unnecessary energy use and cooling demand per inference.
Better routing that minimizes cold starts and evens load can reduce peak/variable demand, easing capacity planning and improving the fit with on-site renewables or energy storage.
Service extensions and unified networking-based APIs simplify deployment and governance, reducing operational complexity for multi-model AI environments.
Improved utilization may reduce pressure to add additional GPUs (and associated supply chain/critical-minerals procurement) by extracting more throughput from existing hardware.

items.title: Where Winds Meet is #RTXOn with DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation

ai.summary: Based on the available description, this NVIDIA GeForce video presents the open-world martial arts RPG Where Winds Meet running with RTX On and DLSS 4 featuring Multi Frame Generation. It invites viewers to experience the title’s visuals/performance enhancements and credits footage to @DigitalDreamsyt.
bullets: Open-world martial arts RPG: Where Winds Meet
Showcases DLSS 4 with Multi Frame Generation
RTX On (ray tracing enabled)
Promotional/visual demo footage credited to @DigitalDreamsyt
takeaways: If DLSS 4’s Multi Frame Generation reduces per-frame GPU compute, gaming/visualization clusters may see lower GPU utilization and energy per rendered frame—worth validating with benchmarks before capacity changes.
Ray tracing (RTX On) increases GPU load and power demand; pairing it with DLSS could alter cooling and power profiles for systems used in real-time rendering or cloud streaming.
Operators of GPU-heavy data centers or edge streaming nodes should test throughput and thermal behavior with DLSS 4 enabled to assess potential for higher concurrent sessions or energy savings.
Adoption of DLSS/RTX features favors GPUs with dedicated AI/RT hardware, which has procurement and lifecycle implications for power, cooling, and critical-minerals sourcing strategies.

items.title: The backbone of your steam plant’s reliability | GE Vernova

ai.summary: Based on the available description, GE Vernova emphasizes the importance of anticipating the remaining life of aging steam turbine rotors and outlines considerations for what to do next to preserve steam plant reliability. The video points viewers to a more detailed resource and frames GE Vernova as focused on electrification and decarbonization.
bullets: Stresses anticipating remaining life of steam turbine rotors to maintain plant reliability.
Addresses next-step actions when rotors approach end-of-life.
Directs viewers to a detailed resource: https://vernova.is/rotor-EOL.
Positions GE Vernova as a leader in electrification and decarbonization.
Encourages subscribing and connecting with GE Vernova for updates.
takeaways: Proactive rotor end-of-life assessment is key to avoiding unplanned outages and preserving reliability for grids and critical sites.
Decision-makers should plan for inspection, evaluation, and remediation options well before rotor failure.
Engage OEMs or specialist service providers early to evaluate remaining life and develop replacement/repair strategies that align with operational and decarbonization goals.

items.title: Rynek dóbr luksusowych w obliczu transformacji | Andrzej Marczak, Tomasz Wiśniewski

ai.summary: Based on the available description, the KPMG ON AIR episode discusses how the luxury goods market is shifting toward experience-first consumption, stronger ESG expectations, and the rise of “affordable luxury,” with Poland bucking global declines and still growing. Experts Andrzej Marczak and Tomasz Wiśniewski highlight customer concentration, personalization, Gen Z preferences for experiences, luxury tourism/hospitality growth, and future drivers such as AI alongside craftsmanship.
bullets: Key trends: experience-driven luxury, ESG/Responsible Luxury (e.g., eco-leathers, certifications), and affordable luxury.
Top spenders concentrated: ~2% of customers account for ~40% of the market.
Personalization and exclusive experiences are central, with Gen Z valuing experiences over ownership.
Poland’s luxury market is growing yet fragmented; growth seen in hotels, spas, tourism and the art market.
Future themes include AI-enabled services, renewed focus on craftsmanship, and the human dimension of luxury.
takeaways: AI and personalization trends imply rising compute and low-latency needs—plan additional data center capacity, cooling, and resilient power for increased processing loads.

Expansion of luxury hotels, spas and tourism in Poland can create localized peak electricity demand—grid planners and operators should assess capacity, resilience and opportunities for onsite generation plus storage.
ESG-driven brand demand for certified low‑carbon supply opens commercial opportunities for renewables (PPAs), green tariffs and certified green hosting from data centers.
Experience-led retail and branded venues may require distributed edge compute and reliable local power—consider modular/edge data centers and microgrids for latency-sensitive services.
Fragmented market growth suggests many smaller, regional deployments rather than a single hub—favor scalable, flexible energy and IT infrastructure to serve dispersed luxury developments.

items.title: PJM: Reliable Electricity is Our Priority

ai.summary: Based on the available description, PJM Interconnection has made reliability its top priority since 1927 and the video explains how PJM works to make sure electricity is there when you need it. It appears to be an overview of PJM’s ongoing focus on keeping the grid operating reliably.
bullets: PJM has prioritized reliability since 1927.
The video explains how PJM works to ensure electricity is available when needed.
Content is presented by the PJM Interconnection channel.
Focus is on grid operational reliability and availability.
takeaways: If you operate substations or data centers in PJM territory, prioritize aligning with PJM reliability communications and procedures.
Factor PJM reliability priorities into interconnection, contingency planning, and backup power strategies.
When deploying renewables or storage, ensure designs and operational plans account for PJM operational requirements and reliability coordination.
Use PJM resources and outreach as inputs for outage planning, risk assessments, and resilience investments.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, power systems need to balance reliability, flexibility, and efficiency while expanding capacity to support the energy transition. Hitachi Energy positions digital-native power grid technologies as a way to improve stability, reduce downtime, and optimize performance across grid assets.
bullets: Power systems must simultaneously deliver reliability, flexibility, and efficiency as capacity grows for the energy transition.
Hitachi Energy offers innovative power grid technologies with digital capabilities at the core.
Digital solutions are presented as drivers of improved grid stability and reduced downtime.
Optimization of performance is highlighted as applicable “at every level” of the power system.
Further details available via the provided Hitachi Energy link.
takeaways: Prioritize digital upgrades in substations and grid controls to boost stability and reduce outage risk.
Plan capacity expansions with flexibility and efficiency in mind to better integrate renewables and storage.
Evaluate vendors on their ability to deliver end-to-end digital solutions that optimize performance and minimize downtime.

ai.summary: Based on the available description, Hitachi Energy highlights energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration as core enablers of resilient industrial operations. Working with customers and partners, they aim to deploy smarter systems that boost productivity, reliability, and sustainability across operations.
bullets: Focus areas: energy efficiency, process optimization, and digital integration.
Goal: build smarter systems in collaboration with customers and partners.
Outcomes emphasized: improved productivity, reliability, and sustainability.
Applies across industrial operations including grid assets, data centers, and renewables/storage.
Link provided for more details: https://lnkd.in/e5vDvrvS
takeaways: Prioritize energy-efficiency and process-optimization projects to strengthen resilience and operational performance.
Integrate digital systems to improve monitoring, control, and coordination across substations, data centers, and renewable/storage assets.
Partner with experienced technology providers to accelerate deployment of integrated solutions that enhance reliability and sustainability.
Treat cross-asset, system-level design (grid, data centers, renewables/storage) as a pathway to higher productivity and reduced operational risk.
